articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7#5 in C# (Shape: G)
articleContent.content:
# Dominant 7#5 Chord in C# (G Shape)

The Dominant 7#5 chord, also known as the augmented dominant 7th chord, combines the notes of a dominant 7th chord with a sharp 5th. In this case, we will explore the Dominant 7#5 chord in the key of C# using the G shape on the guitar.

## Notes and Intervals
- **Root (C#)**: The note that gives the chord its name.
- **Major Third (E#)**: Provides a major quality to the chord.
- **Augmented Fifth (G##)**: The raised 5th, giving the chord its augmented sound.
- **Minor Seventh (B)**: Adds the blue note flavor to the chord.

## Musical Flavor and Genre
The Dominant 7#5 chord has a dissonant and tense quality due to the augmented 5th. It is often used as a leading chord creating tension and enhancing the resolution to the tonic chord. This chord is prevalent in jazz and fusion genres, contributing to the complex and colorful harmonic palette these genres offer.

## Songs
1. **"So What" by Miles Davis**: In this jazz standard, the Dominant 7#5 chord adds depth and tension to the harmonic progression.
   
2. **"Birdland" by Weather Report**: This fusion masterpiece features the Dominant 7#5 chord, enhancing the genre-blending sound of the band.

3. **"Spain" by Chick Corea**: This jazz fusion classic incorporates the Dominant 7#5 chord, showcasing its use in intricate and expressive harmonic compositions.
